title: Thursday, 25th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

So Neil Campling's gone off on one this morning

PM

Neil Campling of Northern Trust

11:01 am
PM

He reckons it's an historic day in the world of Autonomous Vehicles

PM

And he's sharing photos like these....

PM

11:02 am
PM

PM

This is to accompany this, of course....

PM

11:03 am
PM

Singapore getting its first self-driving taxi

PM

Which I think makes the point that all this excitement over self-driving vehciles is way way over the top.

PM

Yes, they might work in small police states, where everyone has to do exactly what they are told.

11:04 am
PM

But they will not catch on any time soon in places where people value their freedom and creativity.

PM

I don't argue with Campling's general peak car thesis

PM

But the idea that within 10 years we'll have dumped our cars in favour of these things?

11:05 am
PM

Nope

PM

I enjoy driving, thank you very much

PM

Let me share some of Neil's stuff in any case

11:06 am
PM

In Manhattan, this total disruption of a transport method took just 15 years. Given the much greater availability of technologies coming together today versus in 1900, we think it will take far less time for the traditional car to disappear from Singapore.

Back in 1898 in Manhattan, it was actually The Horse Manure Crisis that led to a change in transport mode. Yes, there was congestion, but the real reason was health, as three billion flies hatched a day, causing outbreaks of typhoid and infant diarrhoea, on top of the number of people actually killed by horses (per capita death rates from horses in 1898 was higher than road accidents today). In Singapore today, the internal combustion engine causes health problems, but the real motivation of the Singapore government is to cut congestion and the cut the NUMBER of cars on the roads. NuTonomy aims to REDUCE the number of cars needed in Singapore from 900,000 to 300,000. That is an enormous 67% cut. Even if it takes 10 years, that is a compound annual decline few industries can sustain.

PM

n addition to the profound implications this has for the number of cars actually needed in a modern city, there are two additional, very important implications. First, the winner of the race to launch a self-driving taxi was an MIT spin-out - not Mercedes-Benz, not Google, not Uber. NuTonomy has a staff of just 50 and financing rounds have been modest (raised $16M in May). Second, Singapore is like many Asian cities; a high population density, where land is scarce, congestion is high, parking limited and car ownership is being restricted by governments. In our view, driving in China is not like the US (where families drive across the country) but is like a hundred Singapores joined by rail-links. So, if AVs can work in Singapore, they will work in China.

This is not a pipe dream. This is happening today. Imagine what happens when the tens of billions of R&D dollars from OEMs joins the billions being spent today by tech companies on AVs? What we think you will see is a 'ride not drive' culture. Urban dwellers ditch the car that is utilised roughly 4% of the time and choose to watch streamed content on their phones or tablets, rather than driving, worrying about hitting the car in front of them, finding a parking space or making sure insurance is up-to-date.

PM

And a graphic

11:07 am
PM

PM

For the mass market OEMs, this is like a race to the bottom. The urban world will need fewer cars. This is a change in business model many OEMs won't survive. Peak car. Sell OEMs and buy the constituents of our AV Basket: Continental, Infineon, ARM, and Melexis in Europe; DeNA, Sunny Optical, Bizlink, Nexeen and Tencent in Asia and Nvidia, Mobileye, NXPI and Baidu in the U.S.

More here: https://us.aviatel...tonomous-vehicles/

PM

If this was at all likely to happen, wouldnt we have seen a large drop already in car ownership in places like London?

With the rise of Uber.

PM

Have we seen that?

havent seen any figs

BE

Okay. well. Unsurprisingly, I couldn't agree more with the above. And couldn't disagree more with your counterpoint.

BE

First, though we overestimate how much technological advancement will change society within year, and underestimate how much it'll change it within ten.

BE

That's been true for forever, pretty much.

11:09 am

Secondly, car ownership isn't where to look for the Uber effect.

BE

It's driving tests.

And do you have numbers on that front?

11:10 am

I was just looking for new figures. The last DoT data I remember seeing showed tests being sat by the Millennial types (and I apologise for using the term) down by about a fifth.

BE

But that was from a couple of years ago. If anyone has better data, point me at it please.

BE

It's not that people like us will stop driving, it's that our kids will increasingly not see the need to learn.

11:11 am
BE

That's already happening. And it'll accelerate from here.

PM

Just over 4.18 million vehicles were sold in the first half of the year.
That was an 8% increase on second-hand sales in the first half of 2015, and the first time that any half-year sales have risen above the four million mark.
The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said the increase mirrored the rising number of new cars sold in the past few years.

BE

That's car sales. But we're in a car sales bubble fed by cheap credit.

BE

You keep your Jag. But your hearse will be autonomously driven. That's the point.

BE

In terms of the statement .....

BE

Further to the announcement made by ITV plc ("ITV") on 10th August 2016, ITV announces that it has withdrawn its proposal to acquire Entertainment One Ltd ("eOne").

ITV continues to believe in the strategic logic and potential benefits of acquiring eOne but has a clear view of the value of the business, recognising that this value would need to be verified by appropriate due diligence. It appears this value is different to the level at which the Board of eOne would currently engage in a more formal process.

ITV has a clear strategy to build a stronger, more diversified international business and will continue its disciplined approach to evaluating its healthy pipeline of potential investment opportunities.

BE

Largely, building a "stronger, more diversified international business" just means buying non-sterling revenues.

11:19 am

BE

Oh, and I guess we should note that because ETO is not TP regulated there's no six-month lock from ITV bidding again.

hehehe

BE

So, yes, perhaps it's not as dead as it looks. But it still looks fairly dead to me. Entertainment One's a challenging business to value, what with its rather complex use of tax credits and its funding capital lines and etc.

BE

As for other bidders, such as this KKR line reported by Bloomberg: haven't heard anything to encourage that idea, but PE looks at stuff routinely. It's in the job description.

We estimate 17% yoy growth for Epipen in 2016 driven by steady volume
growth (see exhibit 3) and benefit on net price a result of contract renegotiations
following the recall of Auvi-Q in November 2015. MYL had
guided to 8% growth in specialty revenues with price inflation in high
single digits but this assumed competition in 2H which is no longer
anticipated. We estimate normalized Epi-Pen growth of 3% in 2017 driven
by volume. For 2018, we estimate a decline of 10% reflecting potential
generic competition and as such see limited downside to EPS estimates.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 540.50, down 28.5 (-5.01%), High: 563.00, Low: 539.50, Volume: 2.75m
BE

Which is on the back of a Barclays downgrade.

BE

Valuation, mostly.

11:44 am
BE

Though it takes 26 pages to say "valuation mostly".

BE

Just Eat has served up consistent upgrades since its IPO with FY16 consensus
EBITDA estimates having risen some 80% since May 2014. While we still see some
upside to Just Eat’s conservative guidance as it continues to outmanoeuvre the
competition, this is likely to be at a slower pace. The rate of growth in UK orders is
dropping and, with a tough Q3 comp, this could come under increased scrutiny. We
upgrade our estimates and price target to reflect the strong 1H execution, but given
the outperformance of the shares over past months, this is not enough to maintain
our Overweight. We therefore take a pause and reduce our rating to Equal Weight.

BE

An enviable track record and we like the strategic positioning... Our FY16E estimates
suggest Just Eat will have delivered a three-year CAGR in revenue and EBITDA of 57%
and 99%, respectively. This has been driven by positive estimate momentum as a result
of Just Eat’s strong market positioning and solid execution.
...but UK growth rates slowing: Slowing y/y growth in UK orders is partly a function of
the higher base. However, with a slowdown to c. 34% y/y growth in Q2 we calculate
that the absolute quarterly y/y increase in orders is now decreasing. A UK relaunch in
September could help, but with a tough Q3 comp, orders could come under scrutiny.
Logistics operations growing, but segmentation showing through: Deliveroo has
made substantial progress and a recent equity raise of $275m provides further runway.
Our analysis suggests growth is largely due to segment expansion and that Just Eat has
not been materially impacted. The concerns in this area, though, which impacted the
stock in early 2016, have largely dissipated and the share price has recovered.
Time for a pause, downgrade to Equal Weight: Just Eat offers attractive growth in a
tough environment, execution remains solid and EPS momentum is positive, in our view.
However, with increased scrutiny on UK orders, and following an exceptional run, the
shares could consolidate. We increase our FY16/17E EBITDA by a 10/20% and our
TAM/DCF price target to £6.30, implying 38/28x FY17/18E EPS, but downgrade to EW.

11:45 am
BE

(@poitierslimoges: more normal would've been not to invest pension-fund money in a single-asset tax efficient. business with rather cloudy disclosure and a bafflingly low cashflow yield in the first place.)

BE

Quick line on competition I guess.

BE

11:47 am
BE

The relative graph above shows that Just Eat remains substantially ahead of all peers in the
UK, even on a search basis when most of Just Eat ordering will be on already-downloaded
apps. However, it is interesting to note that Deliveroo has outpaced Hungry House from a
standing stand start two years prior, despite Hungry House’s significant marketing push in
2015. In part this may reflect wider interest in Deliveroo as a business, but equally it
demonstrates the progress that Deliveroo has made in expanding the category of online
ordering of delivered food. In addition, we suspect the data for London would show a more
equal split than the chart above shows, given Hungry House is mainly in London and
Deliveroo also, we suspect, is heavily biased to the region.

BE

... But .....

BE

Since 2011-12 there have been a substantial number of new entrants in the US, the UK and
internationally with the focus on last mile delivery. Due to the generous private funding
environment this has become crowded. Vendors in this segment include most notably in
the UK Deliveroo (2012), but also vendors such Postmates (2012), Caviar 3 (2012),
DoorDash (2013), UberEATS (2014) and Amazon Restaurants (2015), the majority of which
are US-based but increasingly are targeting the UK. Due to delivery costs, and with the lower
end of the market already digitalised, these new entrants have focused on the mid-market
restaurant and take-out market, as we have addressed previously. Key is to separate the
noise on this topic from the reality. There are only limited names that matter, but having
seen the impact previously on the stock, we believe it is wrong to ignore the risk to
sentiment from major announcements. Uber is perhaps the focus currently and, with
adverts on its website for UberEATS jobs across Europe4, it could remain a debated name
over the coming period. In addition, it is now planning to expand beyond London Zone 1
and to Birmingham, as it continues its UK launch5.
In addition, we expect that companies such as Uber, with deeper pockets, and a willingness
to invest heavily in the early stages will increase consumer incentives and could potentially
therefore increase the customer acquisition costs across the market. Anecdotally, we have
already noted this with Uber offering a 30-minute challenge whereby the food cost would
be refunded if not delivered in that timeframe. When we tried the service, the food came
after this period and was refunded.

ALLIED MINDS: - INTERIMS
ALM reports no change to its Group Subsidiary Ownership Adjusted Value (GSOAV) of $535.8m - this is in line with expectations given the portfolio valuation already reflects the uplift in value of Federated Wireless (FW) following the $22m funding round in Jan 16. Allied Minds created two subsidiaries during H1 2016; iBeCa Therapeutics (ABLS III) and ABLS Capital and currently consolidates 25 portfolio co.s - we note the group's goal to deliver 4-6 new co.s during FY16, tapping into its relationships with leading US Universities and its favourable access into US Government agencies. ALM has reported group cash of $162.6m as at 30 June ($194.8m at 31 Dec), of which we estimate that c.$95m is at the top co level, with the company highlighting that its current cash and financial position takes it 'through December 2017' and we note the group maintains significant flexibility in the rate of capital deployment across the portfolio and could also benefit from potential realisations. During H1, ALM invested $31.8m and three subsidiaries raised an additional $99.2m in funding from third party investors. We note H1 news flow from ALM; progressing ABLS II into lead optimisation phase, FW began the certification process with the Federal Communications Commission for its Spectrum Access System, entered into an alliance with wireless industry leaders, and announced partnerships with Telrad and Siemens. Spin Transfer (STT) demonstrated its ST-MRAM technology through the production of a working prototype device. We also note recent progress that SciFluor's ophthalmology drug candidate, SF0166, is entering phase I/II clinical trials in H2. Allied Minds is trading at 1.8x NAV.

Market Tech Holdings Ltd (MKT:LSE): Last: 169.72, up 0.22 (+0.13%), High: 171.25, Low: 170.00, Volume: 27.95k
11:54 am
PM

(Frank -- Mark Pritchard? Not really an excess partying sort of chap, i thought)

BE

Anyway, have some Morgan Stanley to summarise where we are.

BE

Summary. Playtech reported strong H1 results, with adjusted EBITDA of €144m
(+27%) being above our forecast (€142m) and consensus (€139m). The outlook
statement is positive, with 19% constant FX growth in the first 55 days of Q3
(10% excluding acquisitions), and it remains "confident in strong growth in 2016
and beyond". It announces a special dividend of 40p / €46c, in addition to a 15%
hike in the interim dividend to €11c/10p, giving a total return of 50p in December
2016. The main positives are the strong H1 revenue growth (24% in constant
currency), high operational gearing with improved EBITDA margin (up 390bps to
44.4% in constant currency) driving strong EBITDA growth of 27% (40% in
constant FX), a confident outlook statement and the special dividend. The main
negatives are a slowdown in current trading and a disappointing performance in
the Financials division. Having delivered 27% EBITDA growth in H1, the company
needs 17% growth in H2 to hit our €306m forecast, with H2 benefitting from c.9%
growth from the BGT acquisition. We continue to see upside risks to forecasts,
and expect consensus (€298m) to be revised upwards. Trading on 9.4x EBITDA
on our 2016e forecasts, we think the valuation fails to reflect the strong growth
profile and cash generation. We outlined our investment case in more detail in
this note.

11:55 am
BE

Group revenue €338m (+18%, MSe €349m). Revenues were a little below our
expectations, with gaming revenues being in line, but a disappointing performance
in the Financials division. Within the mix, casino grew 19% (MSe +14%), with
services +3% (MSe +12%) and sports +10%. To hit our full year forecasts, the
company needs 20% revenue growth in H2, with 18% growth in gaming. The first
55 days are running at +12% in gaming, but this should accelerate through the
period given the contribution of BGT and the launch of Sun Bingo.

BE

"Sun Bingo"! Imagine spending your says playing Sun-branded bingo online. There's a dark world out there of which we have no knowledge of experience ......

BE

Group EBITDA €144m (+27%, MSe €142m). This is above our forecast, with
strong margin expansion in gaming offsetting a weaker than expected
performance from Markets Limited. The underlying EBITDA margin was up
390bps in constant currency to 44.4% (42.6% as reported), reflecting the White
Label business moving from losses to breakeven, and high operational gearing in
the core business. The company also benefitted from some cost efficiencies, and
states that "further margin expansion is expected ahead".

11:56 am
BE

Actually, that gets a bit dull from there. Have Goodbody instead.

BE

Overall, while there are a few negatives in this morning’s results this is generally a positive update from Playtech. In terms of the positives we would highlight (i) the improvement in EBITDA margin; (ii) underlying growth remains solid; and (iii) its strong balance sheet is seeing it return €150m to shareholders without impacting its M&A strategy. In terms of the negatives, while we already knew it is in a period of transition, the financials business performance will be seen as very disappointing by some and currency is a headwind. In terms of our forecasts, we are likely to keep our FY16 EBITDA numbers unchanged at €309m (Core Gaming will increase, offset by a reduction in Financials). Given the better underlying margin the bias to FY17 numbers is to the upside, we currently sit at €350m in terms of FY17 EBITDA. We re-iterate our BUY recommendation.

BE

MYL stock has been under pressure since Bloomberg reports surfaced
yesterday that US Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa sent MYL CEO a letter
citing concerns on the price increases taken on Epi-Pen, potentially limiting
access to the lifesaving medication. MYL is currently priced at a WAC of
~$608 for a 2 pack (2 devices) although this is not reflective of the realized
price increase given rebates/discounts. While the company has taken
approximate 600% list price increases since 2001 (see exhibit 2), to provide
context, the average price remains significantly below chronic lifesaving
drugs – we estimate an annual gross cost (before rebates/discounts) per
patient in the range of $600-$6000 (which for illustration assumes 2-20
injections per year, though typically a patient may use only 1-2). This
compares to chronic lifesaving medications with gross annual cost/patient
for oncology at $100K-$180K, MS at ~$75K, RA at $30-$40K and HepC at
~$50K on a realized basis (exhibit 1), which have also taken significant
price increases. Epi-Pen is a high profile drug given it is used primarily in
children and is the only product on the market for emergency treatment of
anaphylaxis.
